text: Content Standard 1.0: The World in Spatial Terms: Students use maps, globes, and other geographic tools and technologies to locate and derive information about people, places, and environments.

children.text: Map Use
Identify the map titles and map symbols on a variety of maps.
Identify and use the cardinal directions (N,S,E,W) on a compass rose to locate places on a map.
Use maps and map features, including directional orientation, map symbols, and grid system, to identify and locate major geographic features in Nevada and the United States.
Use map elements including scale, latitude and longitude, and projection, to identify and locate physical and human features in the United States and the world.
Use a variety of complex maps to acquire geographic information such as topographic, demographic, and land use.
Map Selection
Describe what a map or globe represents.
Compare uses of maps and globes.
Identify the characteristics and purposes of different maps and globes.
Compare and contrast the characteristics and purposes of several types of maps, map projections, and other geographic representations.
Select appropriate maps, map projections, and other representations to analyze and interpret geographic information.
Geographic Tools and Technologies
Recognize geographic information from maps, globes, photographs, and graphs.
Use maps, globes, photo- graphs, and graphs to collect geographic infor- mation.
Read and derive geo- graphic information from photographs, maps, graphs, and computer resources.
Use maps, graphic rep-resentations, aerial photo-graphs, satellite images, and computer resources to compare Earth's physical and human features.
Use appropriate geo- graphic tools and tech- nologies to analyze and interpret Earth's physical and human features.
Map Construction
Choose a title and construct a key from given map symbols.
Construct a simple map, including title, symbols, and directions.
Construct maps and charts to display information about human and physical features in the United States.
Construct maps and charts to display information about human and physical features.
Construct complex, accurate maps and models from memory to answer questions about the location of human and physical features.
Map Applications
Recognize different types of maps.
Identify the purpose and content of various U.S. maps.
Compare and contrast maps of similar areas for purpose, accuracy, content, and design.
Analyze maps for similarities and differences in purpose, accuracy, content, and design.
Map Analysis
Recognize spatial patterns on a map.
Identify and explain simple spatial patterns on a map.
Answer spatial questions about a map using basic geographic vocabulary.
Make and defend a spatial decision using basic geographic vocabulary and concepts.
Apply concepts and models of spatial organization to make decisions about geographic information.
Map Concepts
Identify and locate land and water on a map or globe, using the terms continent and ocean
Explain the difference between a city and a state, using appropriate examples.
Recognize that states in the United States may be grouped into regions such as the West, Southwest, Midwest, Southeast, and Northeast.
Recognize that countries may be grouped into both physical and political regions, such as Latin America, Oceania, East Asia, Indian subcontinent, and Europe.
Map Locations
Locate Nevada and the United States on a map.
Locate and name states that border Nevada and countries that border the United States.
Label a map of the United States with the names of the fifty states and major cities, such as Washington, D.C., Los Angeles, Seattle, Denver, Chicago, Atlanta, and New York.

Identify prominent countries relative to region or continent and locate major cities of the world such as Beijing, Bombay (Mumbai), Buenos Aires, Cairo, Jakarta, London, Montreal, Moscow, Mexico City, Paris, Sydney, and Tokyo.

text: Content Standard 2.0: Places and Regions: Students understand the physical and human features and cultural characteristics of places and use this information to define and study regions and their patterns of change.

children.text: Characteristics of Places and Regions
Identify basic types of landforms and bodies of water, such as mountains, valleys, islands, lakes, and rivers.
Identify differences between physical and human features.
Describe physical and human features and cultural characteristics of places and regions in the United States.
Describe the relationship between physical and human features, such as landforms and political boundaries.
Determine how relationships between humans and the physical environment lead to the development of and connections among places and regions.
Cultural Identity
Identify traditions and customs that families practice.
Identify how language, music, stories, art, and customs express culture.
Identify examples in their community or region that reflect cultural identity.
Explain how places, regions, and belief systems are important to the expression of cultural identity.
Explain why places and regions are important to cultural identity and can serve as forces for both unification and fragmentation.
Cultural Perspectives
Discuss how people view their own communities.
Describe the character-istics of their community and Nevada from different perspectives.
Compare how cultural characteristics affect different points of view with regard to places and regions.
Compare and contrast the characteristics of places and regions from different points of view.
Impact of Technology
Give examples of how technology is used in the home and classroom.
List examples of technology in their community.
Identify the effects of the use of technology in dif-ferent communities in the United States.
Describe ways in which technology affects how cultural groups use places and regions.
Determine how technology affects the way cultural groups perceive and use places and regions.
History and Region
Identify changes that have occurred over time at home, at school, or in the neighborhood.
Identify an historical landmark and describe the event that took place there.
Identify and describe the locations of selected historical events.
Evaluate the role regions have played in historical events.
Analyze selected historical issues and questions using the geographic concept of regions.
Patterns of Change
Compare visual images of the same place over time.
Describe how their community and Nevada have changed over time.
Describe how and why regions change over time.
Analyze why places and regions once characterized by one set of criteria may be defined by a different set of criteria today, and evaluate these changes.
Applying Concepts of Regions
Identify areas that have different purposes in the home or the classroom.
Identify neighborhoods and communities as places where people live, work, and play.
Identify the criteria used to define different types of regions.
Illustrate the relationship between the physical and cultural characteristics of a region.
Apply the concept of region to organize and study a geographic issue.

text: Content Standard 3.0: Physical Systems: Students understand how physical processes shape Earth's surface patterns and ecosystems.

children.text: Physical Systems
Describe the weather conditions typical to each season in the community and in other places.
Recognize that plants and animals have habitats on both land and in water.
Identify the components of each of Earth's four basic physical systems including atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere.
Explain how the physical processes within each of the four basic systems influence the Earth's surface.
Describe and analyze how interactions of the four basic physical systems affect different regions of the United States and the world.
Natural Hazards
Identify various natural hazards such as floods, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions.
Define and give examples of natural hazards, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and tsunamis.
Explain how natural hazards alter Earth's environments, such as avalanches, wildfires, and drought.
Describe the causes and consequences of natural hazards that shape features and patterns on the Earth
Characteristics of Ecosystems
Identify some basic elements of a simple ecosystem, such as plants and animals.
Identify different types of simple ecosystems, such as ponds, streams, or fields.
Identify the parts of different ecosystems, including soil, climate, plant life, and animal life.
Describe the interdependence among soil, climate, plant life, and animal life within different ecosystems.
Analyze the effects of physical and human forces on interdependence within different ecosystems.
Distribution of Ecosystems
Locate different ecosystems in their community.
Describe the biodiversity of different ecosystems on Earth.
Compare and contrast the biodiversity and pro-ductivity of different ecosystems on Earth.
Analyze the biodiversity, distribution, and productivity of ecosystems across Earth's surface.
Analysis of Ecosystems
Identify the living and nonliving elements of an ecosystem.
Investigate an ecosystem by asking and answering geographic questions.
Formulate a hypothesis about the changing nature of an ecosystem and use appropriate research skills to draw conclusions.
Propose solutions to environmental problems using the concept of ecosystems.

text: Content Standard 4.0: Human Systems: Students understand how economic, political, and cultural processes interact to shape patterns of human migration and settlement, influence and interdependence, and conflict and cooperation.

children.text: Demographic Concepts
Use a school map to construct a visual model of population distribution.
Construct a graph or chart to compare population distribution in different areas.
Explain differences in population distribution within Nevada and the United States.
Describe the characteristics of developing and developed countries using key demographic concepts.
Analyze demographic trends in world population.
Migration and Settlement
Give oral directions from one location to another within their school or community.
Draw a simple map that illustrates how to get from one location to another.
Identify the push-pull factors influencing human migration and settlement.
Describe the reasons for human migration and settlement and explain the effects on places and cultures.
Evaluate the impact of migration and settlement on physical and human systems.
Historical Movement of People, Goods, and Ideas
Categorize different ways to move people, goods, and ideas.
Identify transportation and communication networks in daily life.
List examples of historical movements of people, goods, and ideas.
Describe how a historical event was affected by the movement of people, goods, and ideas.
Analyze how history has been affected by the movement of people, goods, and ideas.
Patterns of Human Settlement
Compare and contrast rural and urban communities.
Describe the characteristics of rural, suburban, and urban communities.
Describe the differences among rural, suburban, and urban migration and settlement.
Identify the different patterns of migration and settlement in developing and developed countries.
Compare the characteristics and patterns of migration and settlement in developing and developed countries.
Economic Systems and Interdependence
Distinguish between goods and services.
Locate sources of goods and services found in the community.
Identify the sources of various economic goods and describe their movement between states or countries.
Explain how the physical and human geography of regions influences their economic activities.
Analyze how location and distance connect and influence economic systems at local, national, and international levels.
Analysis of Economic Issues
Use a map or chart to display information about an economic product.
Investigate an economic product by asking and answering questions about location.
Investigate an economic issue by asking and an-swering geographic questions about location.
Identify a regional or international economic issue and explain it from a spatial perspective.
Analyze and evaluate international economic issues from a spatial perspective.
Patterns of Human Development
Distinguish between wants and needs and describe how people fulfill them.
Compare the wants and needs of people in different communities and the means used to fulfill those wants and needs.
Compare differences in the economic development and quality of life among the countries in North America.
Compare the elements of economic development and quality of life between developing and developed countries.
Predict the impact of changes in the level of economic development on the quality of life in developing and developed countries.
Human Organizations
List different groups to which people belong.
Describe the different purposes of various organizations such as Scouts, organized sports, 4-H.
Describe why types of organizations may differ by geographic region.
Compare and contrast changes in cultural, political, and economic organizations over time.
Evaluate the changes that occur in the size and structure of cultural, political, and economic organizations.
Cooperation and Conflict
Identify places where cooperation and conflict take place.
Describe how cooperation and conflict affect people and places.
Describe issues of cooperation and conflict within the United States.
Compare how cooperation and conflict among people contribute to political, economic, and cultural divisions on Earth's surface.
Analyze how different cultures, points of view, and self-interests influence cooperation and conflict over territory and resources.
International Alliances and Organizations
Identify trans-regional alliances and international organizations that influ-ence cooperation and conflict among countries.
Describe the forces of cooperation and conflict as they affect the way the world is divided among countries.

text: Content Standard 5.0: Environment and Society: Students understand the effects of interactions between human and physical systems and the changes in use, distribution, and importance of resources.

children.text: Changes in the Physical Environment
Describe ways in which changes in the physical environment affect humans.
Describe and predict the regional or global impact of changes in the physical environment.
Compare and contrast how changes in the physical environment can increase or diminish its capacity to support human activity.
Constraints of the Physical Environment
Compare and contrast the opportunities and constraints that the physical environment places on human activity.
Evaluate strategies to respond to constraints placed on human systems by the physical environment.
Technology and the Physical Environment
List tools, machines, or technologies that have changed the physical environment.
Describe places in the United States whose physical environment has been altered by technology.
Evaluate the role of technology in the human modification of the physical environment.
Describe the ways in which technology has affected the human capacity to modify the physical environment and evaluate the possible regional or global impact.
Human Modification
Identify how people shape the physical environment at home and school.
Compare different ways in which people modify the physical environment.
Explore the impact of human modification of the physical environment on the people who live in that location.
Describe the changes that result from human modification of the physical environment.
Develop possible responses to changes caused by human modification of the physical environment
Effects of Natural Hazards on Human Systems
Research a specific natural hazard and document its effects on human systems.
Analyze human perception of and response to natural hazards.
Earth's Resources
Describe ways humans depend on natural resources.
Describe the patterns of distribution and use of natural resources in the United States.
Identify and locate examples of renewable and nonrenewable natural resources.
Analyze the patterns of use, the changing distribution, and the relative importance of Earth's resources.
Management of Earth's Resources
List examples of how people use and manage natural resources within their communities.
Compare the use of the same resource in the United States with another place in the world.
Select a resource and evaluate different viewpoints regarding its use.
Develop policies for the use and management of Earth's resources that consider the various interests involved.

text: Content Standard 6.0: Geographic Applications: Students apply geographic knowledge of people, places, and environments to interpret the past, understand the present, and plan for the future.

children.text: Applying Geography in History
Use visual clues to determine when and where an event took place in the past.
Describe how the physical setting influenced an event in the past.
Explain how different characteristics of people, places, and resources have affected events and conditions in the past.
Analyze the ways in which physical features and human characteristics of places and regions have influenced the evolution of significant historical events.
Applying Geography in Current Events
Recognize the location of major current events.
Identify the location of current events on a map.
Use current events to ask and answer geographic questions.
Explain how the physical geography of a place or region can influence current events.
Relate current events to the physical features and human characteristics of places and regions.
Applying Geography to Contemporary Issues
Recognize a geographic issue or theme that affects home, school, or community.
Discuss a geographic issue from more than one point of view.
Examine a contemporary issue using geographic knowledge, skills, and per-spectives.
Analyze a contemporary issue using geographic knowledge, skills, and perspectives.
Applying Geography to the Future
Plan a spatial change for a classroom or school such as redesigning the playground or changing the location of furniture.
Predict possible geographic changes that could take place in their neighborhood or community.
Describe a geographic issue and the possible impact it could have in the future.
Describe several future outcomes of a geographic issue and defend one possible solution.
Predict possible outcomes and develop future policies for local or regional issues that have spatial dimensions.

text: Content Standard 7.0: Geographic Skills: Students ask and answer geographic questions by acquiring, organizing, and analyzing geographic information.

children.text: Ask Geographic Questions
Ask questions about location.
Ask questions about why things are located where they are.
Ask geographic questions about the origin and significance of spatial patterns.
Identify and define geographic problems and issues by asking geographic questions.
Plan and organize a geographic research project by asking appropriate geographic questions.
Acquire Geographic Information
Gather geographic information from books and pictures.
Gather geographic information from maps, globes, and atlases.
Locate and gather geographic information from a variety of sources.
Use a variety of research skills, including field work and computer resources, to collect geographic information.
Locate and acquire a variety of primary and secondary information sources and assess the value of each.
Organize Geographic Information
Make simple lists and graphs and arrange visual materials to display geographic informatio
Construct simple maps and graphs to display geographic information.
Create complex maps, graphs, or charts to display geographic information.
Create and prepare various forms of maps, graphs, diagrams, tables, or charts to organize geographic information.
Use a variety of tools and technologies to select and design appropriate forms of maps, graphs, diagrams, tables, or charts to organize geographic information.
Analyze Geographic Information
Identify and group in-formation from several geographic sources.
Select and explain in-formation from several geographic sources.
Investigate and interpret information from a variety of geographic sources.
Evaluate and analyze information obtained from a variety of geographic sources.
Use quantitative methods of analysis to make inferences and draw conclusions from maps and other geographic representations.
Present Geographic Information
Display the results of a geographic inquiry.
Create a visual model to illustrate the results of a geographic inquiry.
Draw a conclusion by presenting geographic information in an oral or written report accompanied by maps or graphics.
Make generalizations by developing and presenting combinations of geographic information to answer geographic questions.
Complete a geographic inquiry by applying geographic models, generalizations, and theories to the analysis, interpretation, and present-ation of information.
